Till Birnam Wood ſhall come to Dunſenain.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Can Forreſts move? the Propheſie is good,
If I ſhall never fall till the great Wood
Of B • rnan riſe; thou may'ſt preſume Macbeth,
To live out Natures Leaſe, and pay thy breath
To Time and mortal Cuſtom. Yet my heart
Longs for more Knowledge: Tell me if your Art
Extends ſo far: ſhall Banquo's Iſſue o're
This Kingdom raign?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Enquire no more.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I will not be deny'd. Ha! Cauldron ſinks.
An eternal Curſe fall on you; let me know
Why ſinks that Cauldron, and what noiſe is this.

sp.speaker: 1. Witch.
sp.l: Appear.
appear,
appear.
VVound through his Eyes, his harden'd Heart,
Like Shaddows come, and ſtraigth depart.
sp.stage: A ſhaddow of eight Kings, and Banquo's Ghoſt after them paſs by.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thy Crown offends my ſight. A ſecond too like the firſt.
A third reſembles him: a fourth too like the former:
Ye filthy Hags, will they ſucceed
Each other ſtill till Dooms-day?
Another yet; a ſeventh? I'll ſee no more:
And yet the eigth appears.
Ha! the bloody Banquo ſmiles upon me,
And by his ſmiling on me, ſeems to ſay
That they are all Succeſſors of his race.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, all this is ſo: but why
Macbeth, ſtand'ſt thou amazedly:
Come Siſters, let us chear his heart,
And ſhew the pleaſures of our Art;
I'le charm the Air to give a ſound

While you perform your Antick round.
Muſick. The Witches Dance and Vaniſh. the Cave ſinks.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Where are they? Gone?
Let this pernicious hour ſtand
Accurs'd to all eternity. without there.

sp.speaker: Seyt.
sp.l: What's your Graces will?

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Saw you the Wayward ſiſters?

sp.speaker: Seyt.
sp.l: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Came they not by you?

sp.speaker: Seyt.
sp.l: By me Sir?

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Infected be the Earth in which they ſunk,
And Damn'd all thoſe that truſt 'em. Juſt now
I heard the galloping of Horſe; who was't came by?

sp.speaker: Seyt.
sp.l: A Meſſenger from the Engliſh Court, who
Brings word Macduff is fled to England.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Fled to England?

sp.speaker: Seyt.
sp.l: Ay my Lord.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Time thou' Anticipat'ſt all my Deſignes;
Our Purpoſes ſeldom ſucceed, unleſs
Our Deeds go with them.
My Thoughts ſhall henceforth into Actions riſe,
The Witches made me cruel, but not wiſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: I then was frighted with the ſad alarm
Of Banquo's Death, when I did counſel him
To fly, but now alas! I much repent it,
What had he done to leave the Land? Macbeth
Did know him Innocent.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: You muſt have patience Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: He had none.
His flight was madneſs. When our Actions do not,
Our fears oft make us Traytors.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: You know not whether it was his VViſdom or his Fear.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: Wiſdom? to leave his Wife and Children in a place
From whence himſelf did fly; he loves us not.
He wants the natural touch: For the poor Wren
(The moſt diminutive of Birds) will with
The Ravenous Owl, fight ſtoutly for her young ones.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Your Husband, Madam;
Is Noble, Wiſe, Judicious, and beſt knows
The fits o'th' Seaſon. I dare not ſpeak much further,
But cruel are the Times; when we are Traytors,
And do not know our ſelves: when we hold Rumor,
From what we fear, yet know not what we fear;
But float upon a wild and violent Sea.
Each way, and more, I take my way of you:
'T ſhall not be long but I'll be here again.
Things at the worſt will ceaſe, or elſe climb upwards
To what they were before. Heaven protect you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mad.
sp.l: Farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Madam, a Gentleman in haſte deſires
To ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: A Gentleman, admit him. Enter Seyton.

sp.speaker: Seyton.
sp.l: Though I have not the honour to be known
To you, Yet I was well acquainted with
The Lord Macduff which brings me here to tell you
There's danger near you, be not found here,
Fly with your little one; Heaven preſerve you,
I dare ſtay no longer. Exit Seyton.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: Where ſhall I go, and whither ſhall I fly?
I've done no harm; but I remember now
I'm in a vicious world, where to do harm
Is often proſperous, and to do good
Accounted dangerous folly; Why do I then
Make uſe of this ſo womanly defence?
I'le boldly in, and dare this new Alarm:
What need they fear whom Innocenſe doth arm? Exit.

div.stage: Enter Malcolm, and Macduff. The Scene Birnam Wood.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: In theſe cloſe ſhades of Birnam Wood let us
Weep our ſad Boſoms empty.

sp.speaker: Malcolm.
sp.l: You'l think my Fortunes deſperate,
That I dare meet you here upon your ſummons.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: You ſhould now
Take Arms to ſerve your Country. Each new day
New Widows mourn, new Orphans cry, and ſtill
Changes of ſorrow reach attentive Heaven.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: This Tirant whoſe foul Name bliſters our Tongues,
Was once thought, honeſt. You have lov'd him well.
He has not toucht you yet.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I am not treacherous.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: But Macbeth is.
And yet Macduff may be what I did always think him,
Juſt, and good.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I've loſt my hopes.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Perhaps even there where I did find my doubts;
But let not Jealouſies be your Diſhonours,
But my own ſafeties.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Bleed, Bleed, poor Country.
Great Tiranny, lay thy Foundation ſure,
Villains are ſafe when good men are ſuſpected.
I'le ſay no more. Fare thee well young Prince,
I would not be that Traytor which thou thinkſt me
For twice Macbeths reward of Treachery.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Be not offended:
I ſpeak not as in abſolute fear of you:
I think our Countrey ſinks beneath the Yoak,
It weeps, it bleeds, and each new day a gaſh
Is added to her wounds. I think withall
That many hands would in my Cauſe be active.
And here from gracious England have I offer
Of goodly Thouſands. But for all this,
When I ſhall tread upon the Tirants head,
Or wear it on my Sword; yet my poor Country
Will ſuffer under greater Tiranny
Than what it ſuffers now,

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Alas I find my Nature ſo inclin'd
To Vice, that foul Macbeth when I ſhall rule,
Will ſeem as white as Snow.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: There cannot in all ranſackt Hell be found
A Devil equal to Macbeth.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I grant him bloody falſe, deceiptful malitious,
And participating in ſome ſins too horrid to name;
But there's no bottom, no depths in my ill appetite,
If ſuch a one be fit to govern, ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: O Scotlond, Scotland, when ſhalt thou ſee day again?
Since that the trueſt Iſſue of thy Throne,
Diſclaims his Virtue to avoid thy Crown?
Your Royal Father
Was a moſt Saint-like King; the Queen that bore you,
Oftner upon her Knees, than on her Feet,
Dy'd every day ſhe liv'd. Fare thee well,
Theſe Evils thou repeat'ſt upon thy ſelf,
Hath baniſht me from Scotland. O my breaſt!
Thy hope ends here.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Macduff this Noble Paſſion
Child of Integrity hath from my Soul
Wip'd the black ſcruples, reconcil'd my Thoughts
To thy good truth and honour. Macbeth
By many of theſe Trains hath ſought to win me
Into his Power: And modeſt wiſdom plucks me
From over-credulous haſte. But now
I put my ſelf to thy direction, and
Unſpeak mine own Detraction. I abjure
The taunts and blames I laid upon my ſelf,
For ſtrangers to my Nature. What I am truly
Is thine, and my poor Countreys to command.
The gracious Edward has lent us Seymour,
And ten thouſand Men. Why are you ſilent?

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Such welcom and unwelcom things at once
Are Subjects for my Wonder not my Speech,
My grief and Joy conteſting in my boſom,
I find that I can ſcarce my tongue command,
When two Streams meet the Water's at a ſtand.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Aſſiſtance granted by that pious King
Muſt be ſucceſsful, he who by his touch,
Can cure our Bodies of a foul Diſeaſe,
Can by juſt force ſuddue a Traitors Mind,
Power ſupernatural is unconfin'd.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: If his Compaſſion does on Men Diſeas'd
Effect ſuch Cures; What Wonders will he do,
When to Compaſſion he ads Juſtice too? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Seaton, go bid the Army March.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: The poſture of Affairs requires your Preſence.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: But the Indoſpoſition of my Wife
Detains me here.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Th'Enemy is upon our borders, Scotland's in danger.

sp.speaker: Macb:
sp.l: So is my Wife, and I am doubly ſo.
I am ſick in her, and my Kingdom too.

sp.speaker: Seaton.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: The Spur of my Ambition prompts me to go
And make my Kingdom ſafe; but Love which ſoftens me
To pity her in her diſtreſs, curbs my Reſolves.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: He's ſtrangely diſorder'd.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Yet why ſhould Love ſince confin'd, deſire
To controul Ambition, for whoſe ſpreading hopes
The world's too narrow, It ſhall not; Great Fires
Put out the Leſs; Seaton go bid my Grooms
Make ready; Ile not delay my going.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Stay Seaton, ſtay, Compaſſion calls me back.

sp.speaker: Seaton.
sp.l: He looks and moves diſorderly.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l:
I'le not go yet.
Enter a Servant, who whiſpers Macbeth

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Is the Queen aſleep?

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: What makes 'em whiſper and his countenance change?
Perhaps ſome new deſign has had ill ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Seaton, Go ſee what poſture our Affairs are in.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l:
I ſhall, and give you notice Sir.
Exit Seat.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: How does my Gentle Love?

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Duncan is dead.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: No words of that.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: And yet to Me he Lives.
His fatal Ghoſt is now my ſhadow, and purſues me
Where e're I go.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: It cannot be My Dear,
Your Fears have misinform'd your eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: See there; Believe your own.
Why do you follow Me? I did not do it.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Methinks there's nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: If you have Valour force him hence.
Hold, hold, he's gone. Now you look ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: 'Tis the ſtrange error of your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: But the ſtrange error of my Eyes
Proceeds from the ſtrange Action of your Hands.
Diſtraction does by fits poſſeſs my head,
Becauſe a Crown unjuſtly covers it.
I ſtand ſo high that I am giddy grown.
A Miſt does cover me, as Clouds the tops
Of Hills. Let us get down apace.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: If by your high aſcent you giddy grow,
'Tis when you caſt your Eyes on things below.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: You may in Peace reſign the ill gain'd Crown.
Why ſhould you labour ſtill to be unjuſt?
There has been too much Blood already ſpilt.
Make not the Subjects Victims to your guilt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Can you think that a crime, which you did once
Provoke me to commit, had not your breath
Blown my Ambition up into a Flame
Duncan had yet been living▪

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: You were a Man.
And by the Charter of your Sex you ſhou'd
Have govern'd me, there was more crime in you
When you obey'd my Councels, then I contracted
By my giving it. Reſign your Kingdom now,
And with your Crown put off your guilt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Reſign the Crown, and with it both our Lives.
I muſt have better Councellors.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: What, your Witches?
Curſe on your Meſſengers of Hell. Their Breath
Infected firſt my Breaſt: See me no more.
As King your Crown ſits heavy on your Head,
But heavier on my Heart: I have had too much
Of Kings already. See the Ghoſt again. Ghoſt appears.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Now ſhe relapſes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Speak to him if thou canſt.
Thou look'ſt on me, and ſhew'ſt thy wounded breaſt.
Shew it the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Within there, Ho. Enter Women.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Am I ta'ne Priſoner? then the Battle's loſt. Exit.

div.stage: Lady Macbeth led out by Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: She does from Duncans death to ſickneſs grieve,
And ſhall from Malcoms death her health receive.
When by a Viper bitten, nothing's good
To cure the venom but a Vipers blood.

div.stage: Enter Malcom, Macduff; and Lenox, Meeting them.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: See who comes here!

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: My Countrey-man; but yet I know him not.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: My ever Gentle Couzin! Welcom.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I know him now.
Kind Heaven remove the Means that makes us ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: What looks does Scotland bear?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Alas poor Countrey, almoſt afraid to know it ſelf.
It can't be call'd our Mother but our Grave; where nothing,
But who knows nothing is once ſeen to ſmile?
Where ſighs, and groans, and ſhrieks that rend the air,
Are made, not mark'd, where violent ſorrow ſeems
A Modern Extaſie: there Bells
Are always ringing, and no Man asks for whom;
There good Mens lives expire e're they ſicken.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Oh Relation! too nice, and yet too true.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: What's the neweſt grief?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: That of an hours age is out of date,
Each Minute brings a new one.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: How does my Wife?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Why well.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: And all my Children?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Well too.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: The Tirant has not quarrell'd at their peace?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: No, they were well at peace when I left 'em

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Be not ſo ſparing of your ſpeech. How goe'ſt?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: When I came hither to tranſport the tidings,
Which I have heavily born, there ran a rumour
Of many Worthy Men that roſe into a head,
Which was to my Belief; witneſs the rather,
For that I ſaw the Tirants Power a foot.
Now, is the time of help; your Eye in Scotland
Would create Soldiers, and make Women fight.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Be't their Comfort,
We are coming thither: Gracious England hath
Lent us good Seymour, and ten thouſand Men.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Wou'd I cou'd anſwer this comfort with the like;
But I have words,
That would be utter'd in the deſart air,
Where no Mans ear ſhould hear'em.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: What concern they? the general cauſe,
Or is't a grief due to ſome ſingle breaſt?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: All honeſt Minds muſt ſhare in't;
But the main part pertains to you.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: If it be mine, keep it not from Me.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Let not your ears condemn my tongue for ever,
When they ſhall poſſeſs them with the heavieſt ſound
That ever yet they heard.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: At once I gueſs, yet am afraid to know,

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Your Caſtle is ſurpriz'd, your Wife and Children.
Savagely Murder'd: to relate the Manner,
Were to increaſe the Butchery of them,
By adding to their fall the Death of You.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Merciful Heaven! Noble Macduff
Give ſorrow words; the grief that does not ſpeak,
Whiſpers the o're charg'd heart, and bids it break.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: My Children too?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Your Wife, and both your Children,

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: And I not with them dead? Both, both my Children
Did you ſay; my Two?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: I have ſaid,

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Be comforted;
Let's make us Cordials of our great Revenues,
To cure this deadly Grief.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: He has no Children, nor can he feel
A fathers Grief: Did you ſay all my Children?
Oh helliſh ravenous Kite! all three at one swoop!

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Diſpute it like a Man.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: I ſhall.
But I muſt firſt too feel it as a Man.
I cannot but remember ſuch things were,
And were moſt precious to me: Did Heaven look on,
And would not take their part? ſinful Macduff,
They were all ſtruck for thee; for thee they fell:
Not for their own offences; but for thine.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Let this give Edges to our Swords; let your tears
Become Oyl to our kindled Rage.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Oh I could play the Woman with my Eyes,
And brag on't with my tongue; kind Heavens bring this
Dire Friend of Scotland, and my ſelf face to face,
And ſet him within the reach of my keen Sword.
And if he outlives that hour, may Heaven forgive
His ſins, and puniſh Me for his eſcape.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Let's haſten to the Army, ſince Macbeth
Is ripe for fall.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Heaven give our quarrel but as good ſucceſs
As it hath Juſtice in't: Kind Powers above
Grant Peace to us, whilſt we take his away;
The Night is long that never finds a Day. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady:
sp.l: I have ſeen her riſe from her bed, throw
Her Night-Gown on her, unlock her Cloſet,
Take forth Paper, fold it, write upon't, read it,
Afterwards Seal it, and again return to Bed,
Yet all this while in a moſt faſt ſleep.

sp.speaker: Seat:
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange ſhe ſhould receive the Benefit
Of ſleep, and do the Effects of waking.
In this diſorder what at any time have
You heard her ſay?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That Sir, which I will not report of her.

sp.speaker: Seat:
sp.l: You may to Me; and 'tis moſt meet you ſhou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Neither to You, nor any one living;
Having no witneſs to confirm my Speech.
See here ſhe comes: obſerve her, and ſtand cloſe.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: You ſee her eyes are open.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ay, But her Senſe is ſhut.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: What is't ſhe does now? look how ſhe rubs her hands:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It is an accuſtom'd action with her to ſeem
Thus waſhing her hands: I have known
Her continue in this a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Yet out, out, here's a ſpot.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Heark, ſhe ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Out, out, out I ſay. One, two: Nay then
'Tis time to do't: Fy my Lord, fy, a Soldier,
And affraid? what need we fear? who knows it?
There's none dares call our Power to account;
Yet who would have thought the old Man had
So much Blood in him.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Do you mark that?

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Macduff had once a Wife; where is ſhe now?
Will theſe Hands n'ere be clean? Fy my Lord,
You ſpoil all with this ſtarting: Yet here's
A ſmell of blood; not all the perfumes of Arabia
Will ſweeten this little Hand. Oh, Oh, Oh.

div.head: Scen. II.
div.stage: Enter Donalbain and Flean, met by Lenox.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Is not that DONALBAIN and young Flean, Banquo's Son.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Who is this my worthy Friend?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: I by your preſence feel my hopes full blown,
Which hitherto have been but in the Bud.
What happy gale has brought you here to ſee
Your Fathers Death Reveng'd?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Hearing of aid ſent by the Engliſh King,
To check the Tirants Inſolence; I am come
From Ireland:

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.l: And I from France, we are but newly met.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Where's my Brother?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: He and the Good Macduff are with the Army
Behind the Wood.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What do's the Tyrant now?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: He ſtrongly Fortifies in Dunſinane;
Some ſay he is Mad, others who Love him leſs,
Call it a Valiant Fury; but what e're
The matter is, there is a Civil War
Within his Boſom; and he finds his Crown
Sit looſe about him: His Power grows leſs,
His Fear grows greater ſtill.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Let's haſte and meet my Brother,
My Intereſt is Grafted into his,
And cannot Grow without it.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: So may you both Out-grow unlucky Chance,
And may the Tyrant's Fall that Growth Advance.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Bring me no more Reports: Let 'em flie all
Till Byrnam Wood remove to Dunſinane
I cannot fear. What's the Boy Malcome? What
Are all the Engliſh? Are they not of Women
Born? And t'all ſuch I am Invincible,
Then flie falſe Thanes,
By your Revolt you have inflam'd my Rage,
And now have Borrowed Engliſh Blood to quench it.
Now Friend, what means thy change of Countenance?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: There are Ten Thouſand, Sir,

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: What, Ghoſts?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: No, Armed men.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: But ſuch as ſhall be Ghoſts e're it be Night.
Art thou turn'd Coward too, ſince I made thee Captain:
Go Bluſh away thy Paleneſs, I am ſure
Thy Hands are of another Colour; thou haſt Hands
Of Blood, but Looks of Milk.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The Engliſh Force ſo pleaſe you —???

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Take thy Face hence.
He has Infected me with Fear
I am ſure to die by none of Woman morn.
And yet the Engliſh Drums beat an Alarm,
As fatal to my Life as are the Crokes
Of Ravens, when they Flutter about the Windows
Of departing men.
My Hopes are great, and yet me-thinks I fear
My Subjects cry out Curſes on my Name,
Which like a North-wind ſeems to blaſt my Hopes:

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: That Wind is a contagious Vapour exhal'd from Blood.
What News more?

sp.speaker: 2. Meſſ.
sp.l: All's confirm'd my Leige, that was Reported.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: And my Reſolves in ſpite of Fate ſhall be as firmly.
Send out more Horſe; and Scour the Country round.
How do's my Wife?

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Not ſo Sick, my Lord, as She is Troubled
With diſturbing Fancies, that keep Her from Her reſt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: And I, me-thinks, am Sick of her Diſeaſe:
Seaton ſend out; Captain, the Thanes flie from thee:
Wou'd ſhe were well, I'de quickly win the Field.
Stay Seaton, ſtay, I'le bear you company,
The Engliſh cannot long maintain the Fight;
They come not here to Kill, but to be Slain;
Send out our Scouts.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Sir, I am gone.
Aſide Not to Obey your Orders, but the Call of Juſtice.
I'le to the Engliſh Train whoſe Hopes are built
Upon their Cauſe, and not on Witches Propheſies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Poor Thanes, you vainly hope for Victory:
You'l find Macbeth Invincible; or if
He can be O'recome, it muſt be then
By Birnam Oaks, and not by Engliſh-men. Exit.

div.head: Scen. IV.
div.stage: Enter Malcom, Donalbain, Seymor, Macduff, Lenox, Flean, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: The Sun ſhall ſee us Drain the Tyrants Blood
And Dry up Scotlands Tears: How much we are
Oblig'd to England, which like a kind Neighbour
Lift's us up when we were Fall'n below
Our own Recovery.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: What Wood is this before us?

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: The Wood of Birnam.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Let every Souldier hew him down a Bough,
And bear't before him: By that we may
Keep the Number of our Force undiſcover'd
By the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: It ſhall be done. We Learn no more then that
The Confident Tyrant keeps ſtill in Dunſinane,
And will endure a Seige.
He is of late grown Conſcious of his Guilt,
Which makes him make that City his Place of Refuge.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: He'l find even there but little Safety;
His very Subjects will aginſt him Riſe.
So Travellers Flie to an Aged Barn
For Shelter from the Rain; when the next Shock
Of Wind throws Down that Roof upon their Heads,
From which they hop'd for Succour.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: The wretched Kernes which now like Boughs are ty'd
To forc'd Obedience; will when our Swords
Have Cut thoſe Bonds, ſtart from Obedience.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: May the Event make good our Gueſs:

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: It muſt, unleſs our Reſolutions fail
They'l kindle, Sir, their juſt Revenge at ours:
Which double Flame will Singe the Wings of all
The Tyrants hopes; depriv'd of thoſe Supports,
He'l quickly Fall.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Let's all Retire to our Commands; our Breath
Spent in Diſcourſe does but defer his Death,
And but delays our Vengeance,

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Come let's go.
The ſwifteſt haſt is for Revenge too ſlow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Hang out our Banners proudly o're the Wall,
The Cry is ſtill, they Come: Our Caſtles Strength
Will Laugh a Siege to Scorn: Here let them lie
Till Famine eat them up: Had Seaton ſtill
Been ours, and others who now Increaſe the Number
Of our Enemies, we might have met 'em
Face to Face. Noiſe within.
What Noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It ſeems the Cry of Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I have almoſt forgot the Taſte of Fears,
The time has been that Dangers have been my Familiars.
Wherefore was that Cry?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Great, Sir, the Queen is Dead.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: She ſhould have Di'd hereafter,
I brought Her here, to ſee my Victines, not to Die.
To Morrow, to Morrow, and to Morrow,
Creeps in a ſtealing pace from Day to Day,
To the laſt Minute of Recorded Time:
And all our Yeſterdays have lighted Fools
To their Eternal Homes: Out, out that Candle,
Life's but a Walking Shaddow, a poor Player
That Struts and Frets his Hour upon the Stage,
And then is Heard no more. It is a Tale
Told by an Ideot, full of Sound and Fury
Signifying Nothing. Enter a Meſſenger▪
Thou comeſt to uſe thy Tongue: Thy Story quickly.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Let my Eyes ſpeak what they have ſeen,
For my Tongue cannot.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thy Eyes ſpeak Terror, let thy Tongue expound,
Their Language, or be for ever Dumb.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: As I did ſtand my Watch upon the Hill,
I lookt towards Birnam, and anon me thoughts
The Wood began to move:

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Lyar and Slave.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Let me endure your Wrath if't be not so:
Within this three Mile may you ſee it coming,
I ſay, a moving Grove.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: If thou ſpeakſt Falſe, I'll ſend thy Soul
To th' other World to meet with moving Woods,
And walking Forreſts;
There to Poſſeſs what it but Dreamt of here.
If thy Speech be true, I care not if thou doeſt
The ſame for me. I now begin
To doubt the Equivocation of the Fiend,
They bid me not to fear till Birnam Wood
Should come to Danſinane: And now a Wood
Is on its March this way; Arm, Arm.
Since thus a Wood do's in a March appear,
There is no Flying hence, nor Tarrying here:
Methinks I now grow weary of the Sun,
And wiſh the Worlds great Glaſs of Life were run.

div.head: Scene. VI.
div.stage: Enter Malcome, Seymour, Macduff, Lenox, Flean, Seaton, Donalbain, and their Army with Boughs.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Here we are near enough; throw down
Your Leafie Skreens
And ſhew like thoſe you are. You worthy Uncle
Shall with my Brother and the Noble Lenox,
March in the Van, whilſt Valiant Seymour
And my Self, make up the Groſs of the Army,
And follow you with ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Fare well; the Monſter has forſook his hold and comes
To offer Battle.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Let him come on; his Title now
Sits Looſe about him, like a Giants Robe
Upon a Dwarfiſh Thief.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: 'Tis too Ignoble, and too baſe to Flie;
Who's he that is not of a Woman Born,
For ſuch a one I am to fear, or none.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Kind Heaven, I thank thee; have I found thee here;
Oh Scotland! Scotland! mayſt thou owe thy juſt
Revenge to this ſharp Sword, or this bleſt Minute.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Retire fond Man, I wou'd not Kill thee.
Why ſhould Faulcons prey on Flies?
It is below Macbeth to Fight with Men.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: But not to Murder Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Lenox, I pitty thee; thy Arm's too weak.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: This Arm has hitherto found good Succeſs
On your Miniſters of Blood, who Murder'd
Macduffs Lady, and brave Banquo:
Art thou leſs Mortal then they were? Or more
Exempt from Puniſhment? Becauſe thou moſt
Deſerv'ſt it. Have at thy Life.

sp.speaker: Macb:
sp.l: Since then thou art in Love with Death, I will
Vouchſafe it thee. They fight, Lenox falls.
Thou art of Woman Born, I'm ſure. Exit Macb.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Oh my dear Country, Pardon me that I,
Do in a Cauſe ſo great, ſo quickly Die. Dies.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: This way the Noiſe is, Tyrant ſhew thy Face,
If thou be'ſt Slain and by no hand of Mine,
My Wife and Childrens Ghoſts will haunt me for't▪
I cannot Strike
At wretched Slaves, who ſell their Lives for Pay;
No, my Revenge ſhall ſeek a Nobler Prey.
Through all the Paths of Death, I'le ſearch him out:
Let me but find him, Fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: This way, Great Sir, the Tyrants People Fight
With Fear as great as is his Guilt.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: See who Lies here; the Noble Lenox ſlain,
What Storm has brought this Blood over our
Riſing hopes.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Reſtrain your Paſſion, Sir, let's to our Men,
Thoſe who in Noble Cauſes fall, deſerve
Our Pitty, not our Sorrow.
I le bid ſome Body bear the Body further hence.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Why ſhould I play the Roman Fool and Fall,
On my own Sword, while I have living Foes
To Conquer; my Wounds ſhew better upon them.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Turn Hell-Hound, Turn.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Of all Men elſe, I have avoided Thee;
But get thee back, my Soul is too much clog'd
With Blood of thine already.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I'le have no Words, thy Villanies are worſe
Then ever yet were Puniſht with a Curſe.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thou mayſt as well attempt to Wound the Air,
As me; my Deſtiny's reſerv'd for ſome Immortal Power,
And I muſt fall by Miracle; I cannot Bleed.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Have thy black Deeds then turn'd thee to a Devil.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt but ſhare the Fate of Lenox.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Is Lenox ſlain? and by a Hand that would Damn all it kills,
But thattheir Cauſe preſerves 'em.

sp.speaker: Macb
sp.l: I have a Prophecy ſecures my Life.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I have another which tells me I ſhall have his Blood,
Who firſt ſhed mine.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: None of Woman born can ſpill my Blood.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Then let the Devils tell thee, Macduff
Was from his Mothers Womb untimely Ript.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Curſt be that Tongue that tells me ſo,
And double Damn'd be they who with a double ſence
Make Promiſes to our Ears, and Break at laſt
That Promiſe to our ſight: I will not Fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Then yield thy ſelf a Priſoner to be Led about
The World, and Gaz'd on as a Monſter, a Monſter
More Deform'd then ever Ambition Fram'd,
Or Tyrannie could ſhape.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I ſcorn to Yield. I will in ſpite of Enchantment
Fight with thee, though Birnam Wood be come
To Dunſinane:
And thou art of no Woman Born, I'le try,

If by a Man it be thy Fate to Die.
They Fight, Macbeth falls. They ſhout within

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: This for my Royal Maſter Duncan,
This for my deareſt Friend my Wife,
This for thoſe Pledges of our Loves, my Children.
Hark I hear a Noiſe, ſure there are more Shout within.
Reſerves to Conquer.
I'le as a Trophy bear away his Sword,
To witneſs my Revenge. Exit Macduff.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Farewell vain World, and what's moſt vain in it,

div.stage: Enter Malcolm, Seymour, Donalbain, Flean, Seaton, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I wiſh Macduff were ſafe Arriv'd, I am
In doubt for him; for Lenox I'me in grief.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Conſider Lenox, Sir, is nobly Slain:
They who in Noble Cauſes fall, deſerve
Our Pity, not our Sorrow. Look where the Tyrant is.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: The Witches, Sir, with all the Power of Hell,
Could not preſerve him from the Hand of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Long Live Malcolm, King of Scotland, ſo you are;
And though I ſhould not Boaſt, that one
Whom Guilt might eaſily weigh down, fell
By my Hand; yet here I preſent you with
The Tyrants Sword, to ſhew that Heaven appointed
Me to take Revenge for you, and all
That Suffered by his Power.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Macduff, we have more Ancient Records
Then this of your ſucceſsful Courage.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Now Scotland, thou ſhalt ſee bright Day again,
That Cloud's remov'd that did Ecclipſe thy Sun,
And Rain down Blood upon thee. As your Arms
Did all contribute to this Victory;
So let your Voices all concur to give
One joyful Acclamation.

l.hi: Long Live Malcolm, King of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: We ſhall not make a large Expence of time
Before we Reckon with your ſeveral Loves,
And make us even with you. Thanes and Kinſman,
Henceforth be Earls, the firſt that ever Scotland
Saw Honour'd with that Title: And may they full Flouriſh
On your Families; though like the Laurels
You have Won to Day; they Spring from a Field of Blood.
Drag his Body hence, and let it Hang upon
A Pinnacle in Dunſinane, to ſhew
To ſhew to future Ages what to thoſe is due,
Who others Right, by Lawleſs Power purſue.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: So may kind Fortune Crown your Raign with Peace,
As it has Crown'd your Armies with Succeſs;
And may the Peoples Prayers ſtill wait on you,
As all their Curſes did Macbeth purſue:
His Vice ſhall make your Virtue ſhine more Bright,
As a Fair Day ſucceeds a Stormy Night.
